(3) What do XML Names mean?



Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Combining XML Vocabularies

(4) Name Spaces

  • XML's main concepts (elements/attributes) are using names
  • Names are an important form of identification
  • Names in XML are not suitable for (globally unique) identification
    • They are local to their context (where they are defined)
    • If the context is uniquely identified, the names would be, too
  • Name Spaces: Put names into spaces
    • How to identify the name space? Identifiers on the Web are URIs!


Using XML Namespaces

Outline (Using XML Namespaces)

  1. Motivation [2]
  2. Using XML Namespaces [3]
  3. Conclusions [1]
Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Combining XML Vocabularies

(6) Creating Namespaces

  • It is often assumed that URIs resolve to Web pages
  • A namespace name (a URI) may point to a Web page
  • It may also have no Web page associated with it
  • It is always possible to compare URIs (Do I know this namespace?)


Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Combining XML Vocabularies

(7) Documenting Namespaces

  • Users expect namespace descriptions at their URIs
  • Friendly namespaces provide landing pages (XHTML [http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml] and XSLT [http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform])
  • Some namespaces just provide the schema (SOAP [http://www.w3.org/2001/12/soap-envelope])
  • Unfriendly namespaces may result in HTTP 404 Not Found
  • These all are correct, because the URI is just an identifier!
  • Use search engines to search for namespace definitions


Using XML Namespaces Erik Wilde (@dret): XML Namespaces: Combining XML Vocabularies

(8) Using Namespace Identifiers

  • Namespaces must be used by comparing URIs
    • Everything else is brittle and can break anytime
    • Prefixes have no effect on a name in an XML namespace
  • Treat prefixes as a representation detail
    • When parsing XML, ignore prefixes and inspect namespace URIs only
    • When writing XML, try to create prefixes that are commonly used
